sections.summary: Allah establishes His status as the Living and Eternal, revealing the Book to confirm the **Torah** and **Gospel**. It distinguishes between definitive verses and those that are **unspecific**, cautioning against those who seek deviation through forced interpretation.

Wealth and children are declared useless against Allah's punishment for those who disbelieve, as seen with the people of Pharaoh. The text describes the allure of worldly desires and identifies **Islam** as the only religion accepted by Allah.

Retribution is promised for those who kill prophets and advocates of justice, nullifying their deeds. Allah is praised as the Owner of **Sovereignty** who grants power and life at will, and believers are commanded to love Allah by following the **Messenger**.

The narrative details the selection of the families of Abraham and **Imran**, focusing on the birth of Mary and her miraculous provision in the sanctuary. It records the prayer of **Zechariah** for a son, resulting in the birth of John as a confirmation of Allah’s Word.

Angels announce the birth of the Messiah, **Jesus**, who is granted the ability to heal, revive the dead, and create life from clay by Allah's leave. The verses clarify that Jesus' likeness is that of **Adam**, created from dust, and challenges opponents to a mutual invocation of curses (**Mubahala**) to prove the truth.

sections.theme: Dialogue with People of the Book
sections.summary: The text invites Jews and Christians to common terms of **Tawhid** and clarifies that Abraham was a **Monotheist** (Hanif) rather than a Jew or Christian. It exposes those who twist scripture with their tongues and cautions against taking prophets or angels as lords.

Allah receives a **covenant** from the prophets to support the final Messenger, declaring that any religion other than **Islam** will be rejected in the Hereafter. It notes the severity of the curse upon those who return to disbelief, though **repentance** remains open for those who reform.

True righteousness requires giving from what one cherishes, while legalistic food disputes are settled by referring to the **Torah**. The **Kabah** at Bekka is identified as the first house of guidance, making **Pilgrimage** a duty for those capable.

Believers are exhorted to hold fast to the **rope of Allah** and avoid division, reminding them of the grace that reconciled their hearts. The Muslim community is characterized as the **best community** for advocating virtue and deterring evil.

Disbelievers will not harm the faithful beyond insults, while upright people among the People of the Book are recognized for their night prayers and **prostrations**. Believers are warned against befriending outsiders who harbor hatred and delight in their suffering.

The account of the **Battle of Badr** serves as a sign of divine support, where Allah reinforced the weak believers with thousands of **angels**. Success is attributed solely to Allah's aid, highlighting His authority to forgive or punish.

The text strictly prohibits **usury (riba)** and commands believers to race toward a Paradise prepared for the righteous. It emphasizes that **patience** and **steadfastness** are required to distinguish those who truly strive from those who merely wish for death.

Following the setback at Uhud, the verses remind believers that **Muhammad** is but a mortal messenger and that death is predetermined. It critiques those who faltered due to a desire for worldly gains and records Allah’s eventual **pardon** for the believers.

Rebuking the hypocrites who discouraged battle, the text affirms that Allah alone controls life and death. It commands the Messenger to be gentle and use **consultation (shura)**, while identifying different ranks for those pursuing Allah’s approval.

Those killed in the cause of Allah are described as **alive** and well-provided for, rejoicing in the grace and bounty of their Lord. It condemns the **stinginess** of those who withhold wealth, warning that their hoardings will become shackles on the Day of Resurrection.

The text refutes the claim that "Allah is poor" and reminds all souls that they will taste **death**. The life of this world is characterized as a **delusion**, and believers are warned they will be tested through their possessions and persons.

Reflection on creation provides signs for people of **understanding**, leading to prayers for protection from the Fire. The surah concludes with a promise that no worker’s deeds will be wasted and a final call to **patience**, persistence, and unity.
